raw_comment:
As I analyze the graph, I notice that it is focused on the distribution of admissions advantage at some elite colleges. It is shown that it is 7x more likely to be admitted in a school when having money compared to someone who does not. I can also see how the legacy and parents income can affect the chance of making it into a school. Overall, the graph is informal and helps conclude the rate of college students by emphasizing the distribution rate of legacy admission advantages. 

I wonder why a person's financial status can dictate their education. 

This highly relates to my community being that the majority of the students in my town struggle financially. This will then be harder to get into colleges because of their financial status, discouraging them from going to college at all.

No Money? No Education.
ace_sentences: The graph focuses on the distribution of admission advantages at some elite colleges.
The graph shows a claim about admission likelihood.
A rich applicant is 7 times more likely to be admitted than a poor applicant.
Legacy status can affect the chance of admission to a college.
The income of parents can affect the chance of admission to a college.
The graph emphasizes the distribution rate of legacy admission advantages.
The graph helps to conclude something about the rate of college students.
I wonder why the financial status of a person can dictate the education of the person.
This topic relates to my community.
Most students in my town struggle financially.
If a student struggles financially then it is harder for the student to get into a college.
The financial status of a student can discourage the student from going to college.
The headline is: No money and no education.
